text: hello everyone I'm Rahul Gotham a
security and compliance specialist essay
based in London our customers have used
AWS IM access analyzer to identify
resources shared with external entities
validate IM policies against AWS
recommended best practices and generate
IM am policies for users and roles based
on their access activity now a latest
feature in IM access analyzer simplifies
inspecting unused access to guide you
towards least privilege security teams
can use IM access analyze to gain
visibility into unused access across the
AWS organization and automate how they
right size
permissions in order to ensure your
organization is adhering to the
principal of lease privilege you must
continuously iterate over existing
permissions assigned to i principles to
valuate them and refine them as needed
based on corporate security standards to
avoid permission creep this balances
usability efficiency and security
operating under this principle helps
limit unintended access and helps track
who has access to what resources this is
why we say lease privilege is truly a
journey for example as customers
accelerate their AWS Journey a developer
group may need access to Amazon ec2 but
as they modernize the application they
shift to leveraging Amazon ECS instead
and stop using ec2 altogether after a
defined period of time when you evaluate
that ec2 permissions are no longer
needed you could refine the permissions
of the dev team to remove E2 permissions
and again follow the principle of leas
privilege
however addressing the verification and
refinement of permissions is a
challenging
process I am access analyzer detecting
and subsequently remediating unused
access can help with that challenge I am
access analyzer continuously monitors
and organizes unused access findings
into a summary dashboard security teams
can use IM access analyzer to streamline
the review and refinement of unused
access across the AWS organization using
centralized findings and setup
notification workflows to help
development teams and account teams more
easily refined
permissions now let's take a look at how
this works in practice by walking
through an example AWS account to
identify unused access
findings to enable unused access
findings for your organization you need
to create an analyzer by using the IMA
analyzer console or apis in your
management account or a delegated
administrator account a delegated
administrator is a member account of the
organization that you can delegate with
administrator access for I am access
analyzer I am currently logged into my
delegated administrator account using
the search option at the top let's look
for I
am on the IM console in the left
navigation pane select unused
access our first step is to create an
analyzer let's choose create analyzer
here we can see a couple of options the
first one is external access analysis
which is a feature that allows you to
identify if a resource policy in your
account shares a resource outside your
zone of trust the other option is is
unused access analysis we will be
choosing unused access analysis for this
demo please note that unused access
analysis is a paid feature in the
analyzer details section please provide
a name of your choice to the analyzer I
am going to leave the default value
select a tracking period the tracking
period is a threshold Beyond which IM
access analyzer considers access to be
unused for example if you select a
tracking period of 90 days I am access
analyzer highlights the roles that
haven't been used in the last 90 days
the tracking period is flexible and can
be configured as anything between 1 day
and 180 days customers have experimented
with this time period to come up with
the most Optimum value based on the
security and business requirements
generally a period of 90 days is being
used by a number of customers to
identify unused access and generate
findings accordingly as part of the
lease privilege Journey unused access
analysis can either be performed at an
individual account level or at an
organization level you can consider
enabling it for one account first to
explore the features and then extend the
monitoring to your AWS Organization for
this demo I'm going to enable this for
my entire organization unused access
analysis now lets customers exclude
accounts and IM am principles from the
scope of monitoring by scoping the
analyzer to monitor a subset of accounts
and roles customers can streamline
findings review and optimize cost of
using unused access analysis accounts
can be excluded by entering the account
IDs in a comma separated format or by
choosing accounts from the organization
tree displayed on the console I am users
and roles can be excluded by entering
the tags in them next let's click create
analyzer once created the analyzer
starts monitoring roles and users
looking for permissions that are granted
but not actually used the findings can
take some time to populate and therefore
I had already created an analyze it in
the northern Virginia region for this
demo let's review the summary dashboard
first the summary dashboard provides the
breakdown of all unused access findings
by finding type in a visual format at
the moment my organization has a total
of 242 findings with 195 unused roles
eight unused creden Shields and 39
unused permissions the dashboard also
gives security teams the ability to
quickly gain a bird's eye view of the
findings per account in their AWS
organization and prioritize the next
steps accordingly we will now review one
finding each of unused credentials and
unused permissions types the left
navigation pane select unused access in
the search drop-down list select the
property finding type the equals
operator and the value as unused access
keys to list all the findings of unused
access key type now let's select one
finding from the list to review the
finding details displays the number of
access Keys linked to this IM user and
the last time they were used for example
this IM user has a couple of access Keys
one of which was used 576 days ago and
the other was used 606 days ago the
recommendation section is a new addition
to findings generated by unused access
analysis for unused roles access keys
and passwords IM access analyzer
provides quick links in the console to
help you delete them if we want this
user to continue having these access
Keys we can archive this finding to
resolve the finding next let's look at
one finding of type unused permissions
in the search dropdown select the
property as finding type the equals
operator and the value as unused
permissions
this will list all the findings of type
unused permissions let's select one
finding from the list to review the
finding detail shows the services and
list of permissions within those
services that were not used by the rule
in the tracking period for example none
of the actions linked to easy to
autoscaling were used by this role 106
actions linked to S3 were not used by
this role for unused permissions IM am
access analyzer reviews existing
policies and recommends a refined
version tailored to your access activity
for example in this case access analyzer
found that 106 actions relink to S3 were
not used by this role and recommended a
policy which excludes those actions you
can review the policy by clicking on the
preview policy button customers can
review the recommendations and quickly
apply changes to their policies based on
their security requirements this
accelerating their journey to lease
privilege unused access findings are
sent as events to Amazon event bridge to
receive findings and notifications about
findings you must create an event rule
in Amazon event Bridge you can also send
unused access findings to security Hub
where these findings can be used by
security Hub in its analysis of your
security posture this completes the demo
and that's it today we introduced IM
access analyzer unused access and I
showed you an example where we leveraged
access analyzer unused access to review
findings of unused permissions for an IM
role and identified unused access Keys
unused access is available today in all
commercial regions excluding those based
in China for detailed information see
and review information provided on the
IM AIS analyzer page
